title: 115_hr3479
content: The Act is titled the "Secure Miles with All Resources and Technology Act" and defines key terms such as Commissioner, high traffic areas, Secretary, and situational awareness. SEC. 101 of the Act focuses on strengthening border security technology along the southern border. Section 102 of the Illegal Immigration Reform and Immigrant Responsibility Act of 1996 is amended to include the installation, operation, and maintenance of technology to impede and detect illegal activity in high traffic areas by January 20, 2021. The Secretary of Homeland Security must deploy effective technology along the US border by January 20, 2021, including radar systems, VADER, acoustic detection technology, sensors, unmanned cameras, and aerial vehicles. The section defines high traffic areas as sectors with significant unlawful cross-border activity along the northern, southern, or coastal border within the responsibility of U.S. Customs and Border Protection. Situational awareness is defined as per the National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2017. SEC. 102. COMPREHENSIVE SOUTHERN BORDER STRATEGY. The Secretary must submit a comprehensive Southern border strategy to Congress within 12 months of the Act's enactment. The strategy should include a list of physical barriers, technologies, tools, and cost estimates per mile. The Secretary must provide a detailed account of the necessary physical barriers, technologies, tools, and devices for achieving situational awareness and operational control along the southern border, along with cost estimates per mile. The Secretary must detail the chosen physical barriers, technologies, and devices for each linear mile of the southern border, including existing manmade and natural barriers. Information is collected from various sources such as U.S. Customs and Border Protection Sector Chief, Joint Task Force Commander, State Governor, law enforcement officials, and private property owners. The Secretary must provide a per mile cost calculation for each linear mile of the southern border based on the chosen physical barriers, technologies, and devices. Additionally, a cost justification is required for selecting more expensive options over less expensive ones. The Secretary will eradicate carrizo cane and salt cedar along the Rio Grande River by January 20, 2019. Additionally, a new section titled "Operation Stonegarden" is added to the Homeland Security Act of 2002. Operation Stonegarden program established by the Department for border security grants to eligible law enforcement agencies in border states or territories. Grants can be used for equipment and maintenance costs. The Secretary shall award grants for border law enforcement activities, including equipment, personnel, and other appropriate activities, for a period of not less than 36 months. The Administrator must submit reports to the Senate and House Committees on Homeland Security and Governmental Affairs for fiscal years 2018 through 2022. The Secretary may award grants for border law enforcement activities, including equipment and personnel, for a minimum of 36 months. The report must contain information on grant expenditures by each recipient. $110,000,000 is authorized for grants annually from 2018 to 2022. "Sec. 2009. Operation Stonegarden. SEC. 202. Southern Border Region Emergency Communications Grant." The Secretary, with input from southern border Governors, will create a two-year grant program to enhance emergency communications in the region. Eligibility for grants requires residency or work in a southern border state and increased risk of border violence due to poor cellular and LTE coverage. Grants can be used to purchase satellite communication systems with 9-1-1 access and GPS receivers.
